questions.question_text:
SIMULATION
-

You need to make the shares named Marketing and Sales from SRV1 available on the network by using the following UNC paths:

• \\contoso.com\documents\marketing
• \\contoso.com\documents\sales

To complete this task, sign in to the required computer or computers.

discussion.content: create a DFS namespace named "documents" and within the documents namespace create 2 folders: marketing and sales; then Marketing has to be pointed at \\SRV1\marketing, Sales has to point at \\SRV1\sales; this way users will access "\\contoso.com\documents\marketing" and "\\contoso.com\documents\sales". This is a good way to expose all the fileshares located in different servers from 1 single location

It is related to DFS Namespaces:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/storage/dfs-namespaces/dfs-overview

comments.content: Agreed, the correct process is to create a DFS namespace called documents, and add the shares to it.

discussion.content:
Answer is incorrect.

The question states there are already two shares from SRV1, therefore there is no need to re-create the file shares again.

What you want to do is to make sure when client browse to \\contoso\document\%sharename% they end up accessing the respective shares from SRV1. This involves making changes to domain controllers. Reason being is that when client try to access \\contoso.com, they will end up accessing domain controllers because the domain name contoso.com points to all domain controllers of that domain.

Effectively you will need to create a share named "document" on domain controller, within the share create two shortcuts that points to \\SRV1\%sharename% respectively.

Your network contains an Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) domain named contoso.com. The domain contains the servers shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You need to create a Distributed File System (DFS) namespace that will contain the following:

• A domain-based namespace named \\contoso.com\Public
• A folder named Finance

Which servers can you configure as folder targets for the Finance folder?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
All servers can be a target as long as they have the shared folder.. regardless of Role.. So E

Selected Answer: E
AI agrees with E. 
You can configure any domain-joined server that meets the following requirements:

Runs a supported version of Windows Server (2008 or later).
Has shared folders configured.
If using DFS Replication, the server should be configured for DFS Replication.
Therefore, file servers or any server with proper file-sharing and DFS replication configurations within the contoso.com domain can be configured as folder targets for the Finance folder in the DFS namespace \\contoso.com\Public.

Selected Answer: C
From Microsoft:

Prerequisites of DFS:

The following must be installed to use this feature:

 - A Windows Server with the DFS Namespaces role service installed as part of the File and Storage Services server role. To learn more, see Install or Uninstall Roles, Role Services, or Features.
 - An account with Administrative privileges.
 - A server to host the DFS folder target.
Server2 and Server4 cannot be used as folder targets because they do not have the DFS Namespace role installed. If you have any more questions or need further clarification, feel free to ask!

Server1 and Server3 both have the DFS Namespaces role, allowing them to be configured as folder targets.
Server2 only has the DFS Replication role and cannot be configured as a folder target.
Server4 has no roles assigned, hence cannot be a folder target.

Selected Answer: B
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/storage/dfs-replication/dfsr-overview
Install DFS Replication on all servers that you plan to use as members of a replication group.

You have a server named Server1 that runs Windows Server 2022.

You add two 4-TB hard drives named Disk1 and Disk2 to Server1.

You need to format the drives. The solution must meet the following requirements:

• Disk1 must support disk level quotas.
• Disk2 must support Data Deduplication.

Which type of file system should you use for each drive? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
To meet the requirements for each disk, you should use the following file systems:

Disk1 (must support disk level quotas):

NTFS only (NTFS supports disk quotas)

Disk2 (must support Data Deduplication):

NTFS or ReFS only (both NTFS and ReFS support Data Deduplication, but NTFS is more commonly used for this purpose)

Disk 1 NTFS
Disk 2 NTFS or ReFS only
